Just watched the movie, 'Tron' on IMAX 3D. The 1st half of the movie was brilliant and really captivating, with all the nice graphics and brief yet cool action scenes. But then, as soon as they open their mouths and start talking about what Earth's like, the story behind Clue, and all those boring mundane stuff blah blah blah......, my mind had completely switched off, and it just went completely downhill from there. I was actually dying for the movie to end at that point cos it got so boring. So all style but no substance. Don't get me wrong though, it was totally worth watching it in IMAX and the 3D actually worked in this film to enhance the visuals, and gave you a good sci-fi experience, but it lacked an element of uniqueness and I felt that they could have been more ambitious with the story. Not to mention the fact that the ending was soo unsatisfactory and uber cheesy. If I were to rate it, it would be a 7/10, saved by the amazing visuals and because I absolutely loved whoever played 'Tron'.

Inception review:

Watched it in IMAX and loved it!!! ^__^

I’ll first start by saying that this was another example of Nolan’s finest movies and his stroke of creativity.  Extremely gripping music, compelling yet tricky plot combined with some solid actors is what really sold it to me. Even though it’s a thought-provoking film, his movies always seem to drop a few secret clues to solve the mystery, so I feel he incorporated the same concept and ideology here as well.
 
***SPOILERS AHEAD!!! Don't read any further if you don't want to be spoiled! You have been warned! ***

Although the notion of waking up from dreams, and distinguishing reality from dreams is not a unique one, and has been attempted in several movies, animes, mangas, etc., this was nevertheless an interesting take on an old concept. Furthermore, what makes this different is that he planted a novel little twist here, the fact that if you ‘kill’ yourself in the dream, you ‘wake up’. This is in contrast to previous media that has played with dreams, whereby if you ‘die’ in the dream sequence, you die in reality as well. I thought the way how he showed the subconscious creating mental defences against dream intruders was a fresh thought, but I realised that this was already  in ‘Yugioh’, my favourite manga/anime, in which Yami Bakura and Shadi uses the Millenium key to invade people’s minds. And Yami Yugi’s mind projects as a maze with trap doors designed to keep intruders out from accessing valuable information, which Is a similar concept established in this movie.  

The music definitely kept you awake, and maintained that adrenaline rush and excitement to keep the suspense going. But there was something amiss. Why were the dreamscapes so clean, perfect, devoid of wacky things expected in dreams, and so ‘identical’ to ‘reality’? That, I found hard to believe! Surely, dreams should be more messed up, or mixed with unusual, bizarre ideas, or desires, and none of that was conveyed here. This was either ignored or not tapped into, and this was probably my main criticism of the film.

Nolan definitely played his cards right. The complexity of the film’s plot and the fast pace of the film, left many (myself included) in a perplexed state. Its definitely one that may require 2 or multiple viewings in order to unveil the deeper meaning behind the ending. It certainly is ambitious to show 3 dream sequences happening at one time simultaneously, the no. of layers in a dream (i.e. how many dreams within one big dream), and the different time-frames within each dream layer is what makes it fascinating but confusing at the same time. The slightly ambiguous ending again may invite people to fabricate their own interpretations, but I feel that since this is Nolan we’re talking about, who did ‘Memento’ and ‘Pristige’, im sure there’s a more definite, solid and calculated answer. I, for one think that he was stuck in a ‘limbo’ the whole time, never actually got out of his dream and is living his dream as reality,and that his wife, Mal, was right all along. Heck, I thought he was in a dream from the get-go, but I would need to re-watch it to confirm.

But overall, it’s a definite must-see film, and highly recommended! :DDDD

So...watched 3 movies this month. 2 weeks prior to my exam, i watched 'New Moon' with my best friend(Lin) in the cinema. Gotta say the action sequences were pretty cool,despite the rather dull story. Better than the 1st movie, which was so terribly boring that i almost fell asleep half-way through the movie. And the books, oh god, tried really realllyyyy hard to finish the 1st chapter of the first book, but i found the writing just so unbearably flat and uninteresting, that i couldn't even get past 2 pages...-__- Still don't like Stephanie Meyer's version of pimped out vampires, with totally new additional superpowers. A total betrayal of the average vampire-fiction, i mean i've watched Buffy, i know what vampires can normally do, and mind-reading or pre-cognitive abilities are not one of them! But overall i'd say this sequel was rather satisfying, i liked the chemistry between Jacob and Bella, and when the wolf pack transform into these humungous wolves the size of a grizzly bear. The movie was a good way to distract myself from studying, haha. And last week i watched 'Avatar' in 3D with my brother. Was quite disappointing, with a generic plot, extremely predictable, typical protagonist who gets accepted into this alien race and their society and then switches sides to fight against his own race. Hmm, now what does that remind you of? How about District 9, and The Last Samurai. And the movie just felt like watching a really long CGI cutscene from a game, the world itself, 'Pandora', was like any other sci-fi game, and showed a lack of creativity, with pre-historic animals, floating mountains, and the Navi race themselves were no different than East Africans with their dreadlocks, clothes, tribal face-paint and ornaments. It didn't add anything new. Although watching it in 3D was definitely a plus point and added more depth and dimension, the glasses were such a pain to wear! cos i had to wear them over my normal glasses which was so annoying cos it kept falling and slipping off my nose...>__< Anyway, the movie was not worth the money, apart from the gorgeous visuals and CG, and the heroin's amazing voice-acting, there was really nothing that grabbed my interest. All in all, a rather forgettable movie, what a pity!:( 2 days ago, i downloaded 'Blood: The Last Vampire', cos i felt a duty, as a fan of the anime movie and the series, to see how well the adaptation was. Apart from the horribly cheesy dialogue, and the fake looking blood, I found the action sequences really impressive. Anyway, enough about my house...i hope everyone is doing fine alhamdolilah and that everyone's in good health :D

Oh yeah, my module for this term is on "Neuroscience"!!!!!!!! Its SOOO amazing!!! Ahhhh... the most interesting modules i have come across so far, very heavy and complicated but oh so interesting!!! I'm totally loving it!!! ^O^  So today in my SSC (student selected component) session, we were debating quite deeply on whether there is a 'God' spot/lobe, or a neuroanatomical variability in the brain thats responsible for 'religion', cos the SSC i chose to do was 'fMRI brain imaging of religious experience'.  Then we were talking about how many scientists are still troubled by the 'persistence' of religion for decades, even suggesting that religion may have some kind of 'survival advantage', as people with religion tend to be less prone to mental illnesses...? hmm.....what a strange thought.... Our teacher then deviated completely and started asking us about how we percieve mental illness with 'possession' and the whole 'glossolalia' concept ('speaking in tongues') which is the idea that some people can speak God's words/messages from a divine above, said to be elicited when under an intense prayer or intimate connection to God, almost as if they are being possessed at that moment (not in control of themselves) to say this nonsensical, unknown language. But to us normal people, it would sound as something completely gibberish and incomprehensible. Some say it can be translated, others say it's a language out of this world. But no one really knows what brings about this bizarre phenomenon...there has been research showing certain areas of the brain becoming active during glossolalia, like increased 'temporal lobe activity'. But yeah, our teacher has a habit of deviating and going off-topic a bit, but its hard not to go on a 'philosophical' tangent during these discussions (which is what we normally end up doing..hahha, lol!)  

Here's a youtube video, if you're interested in knowing more about 'glossolalia': http://video.google.co.uk/videosearch?hl=en&resnum=0&q=glossolalia&um=1&ie=UTF-8&sa=N&tab=wv#

There are 8 of us, with 4 of us declaring ourselves as 'religious' and the other 4 being 'non-religious' (I obviously was in the religious group) and basically we discuss loads of articles and critically evaluate these research papers (all of which involve some form of brain imaging perfomed a group of participants while they are having a 'religious experience' to see which areas of the brain light up and whether these loci of activation were different from non-religious people. ('religious experience' ofcourse, being a very non-specific and broad term involving any sort of 'union' , meditation, prayer or spirituality with 'God', its hard to define, really.) SO anyway, I'm gonna have my 'fMRI brain scan' done next week, for the purposes of our teacher's research!!!! SOOO looking forward to it!!! ^_______^
Apparently, all we've been told so far, is that during the fMRI, we're going to perform a task which involves looking at a pair of words being displayed on a screen, and pressing a button when you see the pair of words 'rhyme'....yeah...pretty vague description, right? O__O The teacher doesn't want to disclose anything more for fear of it influencing our thinking/actions during the brain scan. And how that relates to having a religious experience beats me!!! but it'll be fun! :DDD  

Anyway, i hope everyone's fine and doing well.

Until then, take care everyone!!!

man, i had SOOO much fun dissecting the heart today from our cadaver!!! (who btw, is an old petite lady , we named her 'Maggie' which is short for Margaret, who died of small bowel infarct and atrial fibrillation..yumm) Her heart was MASSIVE! seriously, we had the biggest heart from out of all the other groups, most likely due to hypertrophy , and atrial dilation of the heart, resulting in atrial fibrillation. Thats the reason why her right atrium was HUGEEE!!!!!! *___*  it was even bigger than the ventricles, and while I was trying to clean the right atrium, this huge blood CLOT came out!!!! O__O like the size of a fist!!! >__< and was rock solid, almost black in colour....its insane, i tell you. So i think it was because the clot/thrombus in the small bowel must have migrated and travelled up to the heart and occluded the right atrium, resulting in her death. Ahh scalpels and forceps are soo much funsies! i love playing with them around (although i heard that yesterday, one medical student had dissected her thumb because she didn't know how to unload the scalpel blade out, and it sliced through her thumb!!! oucchhh!!! >__________< cos these scalpels are dangerously SHARPPP!!!!!)  i seriously think i might want to pursue some form of 'surgery' in the future tho, its just SOO exciting and such a rich experience! :DDDD not that ill ever be as good a surgeon as my dad, but hey...im considering it XDDD. you never know, right? ;) i dunno, i sorta feel this 'buzz' and thrill inside me in dissection sessions, and get really keen on cutting dead bodies up, ok..thats not quite the right way to phrase it, heh ;^^; d..d..don't misunderstand!!! 

 anyway, it took us a total of 3 HOURS to finish dissecting it,as well as looking at all the coronary vessels, fine structures, and the interior part of the four chambers, but it was SOO worth it! Oh yeah, her fossa ovalis (foramen ovale) wasn't very visible because of all the blood clots obscuring our view, but the concept of it being there is very interesting. I was wishing our cadaver might have a 'patent' fossa ovalis, because its quite rare, but i guess it wasn't meant to be *sighhh*

Ahhh its great when after my dissection lessons, I always somehow feel really hungry, whereas i thought the sight of all the muscular meaty bits in the cadaver would put you off meat, and decrease your apetite, but actually its quite the contary, it makes chicken even more appetising and tasty-looking. hehehee XD or maybe thats just my demented, morbid perspective? yeah, i must be weird in the head XD.

Two children got killed by stabbing yesterday. My dad, who works in the Accident and Emergency department, had night duty last night so he was there to operate on two of the children, they had stab wounds on their necks from a knife attack. Three siblings were attacked, but unfortunately the eldest, who was a 5 year old boy, died before reaching the hospital. The other two were a 4 year old girl and a 6 month old baby girl who were admitted to ST. Helier Hospital, where my dad (including me) works. my dad was able to save the 6 month old baby ( she was later transferred to the London's Children Hospital, and her current state has improved) who was also stabbed but the cut was not as deep as the older girl's, who had been stabbed through the neck which also pierced into one of the lungs. Although my dad opened her chest to stop the lung from bleeding and sutured it up, she had already lost too much blood from her neck wound, and despite the medical team's best efforts to resuscitate her for an hour, she didn't survive. My dad was about to suture the chest and close it back, but then the police came and announced that this was a crime scene, and that they were not allowed to remove anything or touch the body as post-mortems were going to be carried out, so he had to leave it open. You can read more about the incident here, on the BBC website: http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/london/7428946.stm (there's also a video on the bottom of the website which shows my dad's hospital) This bit of news even appeared on the T.V. as one of the main Headlines on BBC. My dad was really upset last night and he even cried mostly because the kids were so young, and didn't deserve having their innocent lives cut short. Its such a shock, really, to think that there are parents who would do such a cruel and terrifying act to their kids, and try to murder them. Its unthinkable. I mean if they don't like kids, then why give birth to them in the first place? And im curious, who actually did call the police? Was it the mother, cos she had some minor injuries as well, so perhaps it was the father who tried to kill them, and the mother tried protecting her kids? Let us hope that whoever murdered the two kids is punished and that the young baby girl recovers soon. Its just really sad :(
